awd_titl_txt: Research Initiation: Collaborative Research: Understanding pedagogically motivating factors for under-represented and non-traditional students in an engineering classroom
awd_abstract_narration:
With the increased use of online educational lessons to complement face-to-face instruction in universities and colleges nationwide, it will be important to understand how these forms of instructional aids help students to engage, garner interest in, and excel in their courses. In the areas of science, technology, engineering, and math, little is known about how these electronic instructional tools can be designed to motivate students to engage with concepts that are fundamental, yet difficult to master.  In particular, we aim to explore how these types of instructional aids influence the engagement and interest of students from underrepresented groups and women in the field of engineering.  Special focus will be given to courses and online instructional aids for topics within engineering where drop-out rates are known to be high among students (e.g., engineering statics). 

One unique element of this work is that research methods in fields like neuromarketing will be incorporated into this study where biometric responses will be observed as students engage with online engineering instructional aids.  Biometric responses are physiological characteristics of the human body such as eye tracking and skin conductance. The study will explore what motivated or demotivated underrepresented populations to persist in using the instructional aid and how their experience with these educational electronic tools influence the motivations towards continuing in the field of engineering.  A broader impact of this work is that by understanding how online instructional aids engage and motivate students, we can understand how to better design electronic tools and apps that will enable a wider range of students to pursue and succeed in engineering. The intellectual merit of this exploratory, mixed-method multi-modal research study is to understand the intertwined mechanisms (i.e. the motivational, affective, attentive, and physiological influences) of underrepresented and non-traditional women in engineering as they engage in online instructional aids and tools. In addition, this work will inform the Technological Acceptance Model to better understand and measure the associations between these constructs. While the model aims to understand the influence of extrinsic motivators such perceived usefulness and ease of use of specific technologies that determine an individual's behavior or choice to use/benefit from a specific technology; it does not meaningfully allow for contextual analysis of subgroups within engineering such as gender, race/ethnicity and age, as well as and their intersectionality within engineering.  This exploratory work will help advance the knowledge-base in engineering education around the development of engineering-specific theories and pedagogy for educational electronic learning tools with emphasis on understanding the mechanisms that intersectionality plays in their acceptance, learning and engagement.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Educational communities have widely explored educational games for enhanced student engagement and performance over the last two decades.  The engineering, science, and math disciplines have studied the subject extensively. These previous studies, however, focused on undergraduate communities as a homogenous group, thus masking the perspectives of underrepresented groups within engineering.

This project established a new field of engineering education research aimed at understanding how the emergence of online intuition-based engineering gaming technology in 21st century classrooms impact marginalized women of color in engineering. This project addressed a deficit in the literature on educational engineering games, which had omitted the experiences of women and in particular, women of color. Intersectional women of color within the engineering population reside at the intersection of marginalized racial and gender groups. Intersectionality recognizes the juncture where gender and race intersect and can create anxiety, mental and emotional health problems among individuals who are expected to represent their entire race or gender. Prior to this project, few, if any, studies existed with this group in mind when designing intuition-based online engineering learning games and applications.

This project established the groundwork for critical examination of intuition-based engineering online education games from the perspectives of intersectional women. Game design, user interface, scaffolding, sound, and educational content, in particular,  were related to undergraduate students? engagement, game performance, and motivation to continue engaging with the game. To establish this research area, two theoretical models were leveraged: Intersectionality and the Technology Acceptance Model (TAM). This work extended the TAM by helping researchers understand how an individual?s extrinsic motivators, such as perceived usefulness, ease of use and personal characteristics such as ethnicity, background, and gender influenced users? behaviors with respect to an engineering learning online game.

The RIEF: Understanding pedagogically motivating factors for under-represented and non-traditional students in an engineering classroom project also explored the use of a multimodal research method to examine student experiences of engineering games. This foundational study helped to expand the use of this burgeoning research approach and further demonstrate its efficacy. The multimodal approach in this work helped to connect students? experiences and reaction to game play (via physiological markers e.g., attention and emotion) to their responses in surveys and interviews. Hence, this multimodal methodology helped extend how these investigative techniques could be beneficial in establishing meaningful links between student qualitative and quantitative data, and physiological responses.

Findings have been disseminated to engineering and educational research audiences via publication and presentations. Work to date suggests that women and people of color have a less exposure and experience in the use of online educational science and engineering gaming technology, which influences their performance in certain types of learning tools that rely primarily on intuition and trial and error formats for knowledge acquisition and scaffolding. Access to mobile applications and computers, along with awareness of these forms of learning tools were shown to also be linked to this groups? performance in the engineering game. Paradoxically the results also indicate that women and people of color have higher expectations and interest in learning from these forms of learning tools than their non-white and male counterparts. To date, this project has also resulted in one validated protocol, four published conference proceedings articles; three conference presentations, one published journal article; and one journal paper in development, which have been published in open-access portals for public dissemination.

This work has reached the engineering education community not just at the research institution, but also other institutions within and outside of the United States. This work has also shown that as use of online engineering learning modules and games become ubiquitous in engineering classrooms, developers must be conscious of intersectional experiences and voices which undoubtedly inform the professional formation of these groups into engineers.
